qas.question: What usually changes when a place observes DST?
What word does American English swap out for "daylight" when referring to time zones?
In American English, what is the equivalent of Pacific Standard Time?
When the UK changes their clocks forward in the spring, what do they call the time they're then observing?
What word is often added to the names of time zones when used in British English?

context: <a0_0>The name of local time<a0_0/> typically changes when DST is observed. American English replaces <a1_0>standard<a1_0/> with daylight: for example, Pacific Standard Time (PST) becomes <a2_0>Pacific Daylight Time<a2_0/> (PDT). In the United Kingdom, the standard term for UK time when advanced by one hour is <a3_0>British Summer Time<a3_0/> (BST), and British English typically inserts <a4_0>summer<a4_0/> into other time zone names, e.g. Central European Time (CET) becomes Central European Summer Time (CEST).
